full_conversation: Therapist: Let's begin the exposure exercise. Remember, you're safe here. Can you describe the day of the airplane crash?
Client: It was a sunny day in July. We were supposed to go on a family vacation. My husband, our son, and I were at the airport, waiting for our flight. Everything seemed normal at first...
Therapist: You're doing well. Continue.

Client: We boarded the plane, found our seats. I remember feeling excited about the trip. The takeoff was smooth, but about 30 minutes into the flight, there was a loud bang. The plane started shaking violently...
Therapist: Stay with that moment. What did you feel?

Client: I felt... terrified. My heart was racing. I grabbed my husband's hand and looked at our son. He was pale, his eyes wide with fear. The oxygen masks dropped down, and there was chaos all around us.
Therapist: You're being very brave. Keep going.

Client: People were screaming. The flight attendants were trying to calm everyone down, but I could see the panic in their eyes too. I was fumbling with the oxygen mask, trying to put it on our son first, then myself...
Therapist: That must have been incredibly frightening. What happened next?
Client: The plane was losing altitude fast. I could feel my stomach dropping. I kept thinking, "This can't be happening. This can't be real." I held onto my family tightly, praying for a miracle...
Therapist: You're doing great. Take a deep breath.

Client: (takes a shaky breath) Then came the impact. It was... it was like nothing I've ever experienced. The noise was deafening. Everything was shaking, breaking apart. I lost my grip on my husband and son...
Therapist: It's okay to feel upset. You're safe here.

Client: (voice breaking) When the plane finally stopped moving, I was upside down, still strapped to my seat. I could smell fuel and smoke. I called out for my family, but I couldn't hear their voices...
Therapist: You're being so strong. Continue when you're ready.

Client: I managed to unbuckle myself and crawl out of the wreckage. There was debris everywhere. I was calling out for my husband and son, searching desperately. Other survivors were stumbling around, injured and dazed...
Therapist: How are you feeling right now?
Client: I feel... overwhelmed. My chest feels tight, and I can almost smell the smoke again. It's like I'm back there...
Therapist: That's normal. Remember, you're here now, safe.
Client: (nods) I searched for hours. Rescue teams arrived, but... (starts crying) they couldn't find my husband or son. They were gone. Just like that, in an instant, my whole world shattered.
Therapist: It's okay to cry. You're doing incredibly well.
Client: I keep replaying that day in my mind. Wondering if there was something I could have done differently. If I had insisted on a different flight, or if I had held onto them tighter...
Therapist: Those thoughts are common, but not your fault.
Client: I know, logically. But emotionally... it's so hard. I miss them every day. The pain never really goes away. It just... changes.
Therapist: You're showing immense strength. How do you feel now?
Client: Drained. Sad. But also... a little relieved? It's hard to talk about, but it feels important to remember them, to honor their memory.
Therapist: That's a very healthy perspective. Well done today.
Client: Thank you. It's still difficult, but I think these sessions are helping me process everything. I want to keep working through this.
Therapist: I'm glad to hear that. We'll continue next time.
